CHARLES POLK, Governor of the said State.
10 all persons to whom these presents shall come.
WHEREAS, on the first Tuesday Of October,
being the second day of that month, in the year ofl
our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and Twen-
ty-seven, Elections tor choice Of Representative
oi and Tor the SAID State, in the twentieth Congress
OF the United States, IN lieu OF the Honorable Louis
Nj lane, and to supply the vacancy in the Represen
tatlon OF this State, occasoned by his election to,
and acceptance of, the office of Senator for this
State in the Senate OF the United States for the term
OF six years from the fourth day of March last past
were held according to the laws of said State, in the
several Counties thereof, in obedience to wrs of
election for that purpose issued And whereas,
returns for the said elections, in due manner made
out, signed and executed, have been delivered to
me, according to the laws of the said Stae by the
respective Sheriis Of the said Counties, and having
examined SAID returns, and enumerated and
tanned the number of votes, for each and every
didate person voted for as such Representative,
have. found Rensey Johns, Junior, Esquire, to be
the person highest in vote, and therefore duly cleo
ted the Representative of, and for the said State in
lieu of the Honorable Louis M.Lane and 10 supply
the vacancy i'll the Representation of this State for
the Twentieth Congress, in the House of Repre-
sentatives of the United States.


!, the said Charles Polk, Governor aforesaid, do
therefore, according to the form of an act of the
General Assembly Of the said State, in such case
made and provided, declare the said Kensey Johns,
Junior, the person highest in vote at the election
aforesaid, and therefore duly elected the Represen-
latye of and for the said State of Delaware to sup
ply the vacancy aforesaid in the Twentieth Congress
Of the United States.


Given under my hand and the Grca


Seal. Seal of the State, at Dover, this eleventh


S,....s day Of October, in the year Of our Lore
One Thousand Eight Hundred and Twenty
and of the independence Of the said State the Fifty
second,


CHARLES POLK,


BY the Govcrnor.


JOHN NJ. CLAYTON, Secretary of State.

THIS Institution will be opened on Monday


the 25th of October Inst, under the care


ofthe Rev. JOSEPH WlLsoS


Tn this Seminary students will be thoroughly in
sructed in the different branches of good English
and Classical Education, viz: Reading. Writing,
Arithmetic, English Grammar, Geography, Comp"-
sit,on. Elocution, Mathematics, and the Greek and
Latin Languages The terms OF tuition will be TOR
the English branches, exclusive of Mathematics,
So per session, or $40, including the Mathematics
for the Languages, including the fnsi'sn' sio per
session. Tuition money to be paid In advance.


There will be two sessions in the year, with
short vacation between each.


Good boarding can be obtalred in respectable,
families in the village, at the rate of Forty Dollars
nor session and few boardcrs can be accommo-
dated in the family of the Principal.


JOHN EDDOWES. Sec'y.

Loved friend and father of the American people,

There is, however, one circumstance connected with
the burning of the tea at Annapolis that should nut
be forgotteD and in which highly respected and
valued friend of Mr.. Carroll partici pated.


The late Dr. Charles Alexander Warfied, of
Anne Arundel county, who but short time before
had obtained professional honors IN the University OF
Pennsylvania, and had been appointed major Of Bat
talon, upon hearing of the arrival of the brig
;. Peggy Steaca1'' at Annapolis, loaded with tea,
and which vessel belonged to Mr.. Anthony Stewart,


"a Scotch merchant) put himself at the head OF the
..Whig Club,' Of which he was distinguished
member. and marched to Annapolis with determl-
nation to burn vessel and cargo. When this party
arrived opposite the State House. the late Judge
Chase met them, and harrangued them, (he had been
employed as lawyer by Mr.. Stewart.) DIR. War
field, finding that he was likely to make some i'm


preston upon the minds of his company, interrupt


ed him by observing that Chase had by former patri-


otto speeches made to the . Whig Clubs" lnAamed


the whole country, and now wished to get ON by his


own light; and pronounced 1T SUBMISSION or cow


ardce in any member of the club TO stop short OF


their object and called upon the men to follow
him. that he would himself set fire to the vessel and


cargo but it is stated, upon the best authority, that


the doctor carried in his hand the chunk Of fire IN


company with Stewart, whom he made to kindle 1t.


When the party first entered the city and was pas


sing on. they met Stewart, who was bold IN oppps-


tlon and threatened them with the vengeance OF his


king and government, but his threats seemed ony to
Iatp n ual-


lows directly in front of his house, by way OF lntnl-


iation then gave him his choice, either to swing by


the halter, or 20 with them on board Hd put lire to
his own vessel he chose the latter, and in lew
b moments the whole cargo, with ship tackle and
h apparel, were in flames shortly after this, Mr
. Stewart left the country. This act decided the
J. course Maryland TO pursue. and had an exten
!. sve influence upon public opinion.


. The writer of this IN company with Judge

{ From tile Baltimore Patriot Sept 27.


REVOLUTIONARY IiEROISM.

AZ
4th Of June, 752 in Baltimore county, in this state.
Ills grandfather, Joshua Howard. an Engshnan by
birth. having while yet very young, let his fathers
house in the vicinity of Manchester. to join the army
of the duke Of York, subsequently James II. during
Moumouth's insurrection, was afterwards AFRAID to
encounter his parents dspeasure, and came 10


seek his fortune in America. This was IN the year


lG85-s6. He obtained grantof the land in BaitlA


more county. on which Col. Howard was born,


and which is still in the family, and married Miss


Joanna CARROLL whose father had lately emigrat-


e. from Ireland. Cornelius, one OF his SONS ny this


lady, and father of the subject of this sketch mar


red Miss Ruth Eager. the grand daugh.er of George


Eaoer. whose estate adioined and now makes con-


siderable part of this city. The Eagers came from


England probaby soo after The charter toLord Bali
timore but the records afford little information


prior to 668. when the estate near Baltimore was
purchased. - s


cuIar profession, was destined to that OF arms


by the circumstances of his country. One OF the
first measures Of defence adopted by the colonies
against the mother country was the assemblage OF
4 bodies of the militia, termed flying camps. One OF


these was formed in Maryland in l776, and Mr..


Howard was appointed to Gapta,ncy IN the res'-


ed By Matthew 'Tlghman, the President Of the Cone


yentien of Maryapd is dated the 25tho June, 1776s


a few davs ater he had completed his twenty fourth
year. This corps was dismissed, however, IN the


December of the same year, Congress having rec


qured of each of the states to furnish certain pors


ton Of regular troops, as more effective system
of defence. On the organization OF the seven reSl-
, ments which were to be furnishedby Maryland Cap.
tain Howard, who had been retained by the wish OF
! the Commissioners empowered to appoint officers,
rather than his own, was promoted TO MAJORITY IN


one or tbem the Fourth, under his former comiaile


der, Col. Hall.-His commission IS dated the loth


of Aprl, lT77. On the first June. 1779 he was ape


nointpl Lieutenant Colonel OF the Fifth and IN the


following spring he was transferred to the Sixth, and
: finally after the battle of Hnbkic&s Hill, he succte+


ded to the command of the Second in consequence
! of the death of Lieutenant Colonel Ford, who ne4
= yer recovered of wound received IN t'at battle.
- - OF the services of Colonel Howard during these
" ', wears. and throughout the we have not iimss
y ~ nor is it necessary to speak. In the chvalrous and
: hazardous operations OF Greene in the South, he was
one Of his most efficient and conspicuous coaf5uors.
That gallant General, exact discrimination Of
"a merit pronounced hias coed an officer as the world
= afforded 10 have the best dispositions and corress


pendent ability, to promote the service and to hava
- conf rred great obligations HIMSELF AMI greater
b. on the public. lie deserves said Greene stas
~, tue of gold no less than Roman and Grecian hes


u roas - At the battle of Cowpcns, says Lee, he
,d seized the teal moment, and turned the fortune
"a of he day. He was alike conspicuous, though not
!, alike successful at Guord and the Eutatvs and


- at MI times aud on all occasions eminently useful
vi Besides the battles Just mentioned, he was IN the
!. engagements of White Plains, of Germantown, Of
be Monmouth Camden tlobkick's Hill and others,
ok which may be known to our readers. Having been
IL trained to the service, he employed in that lines
H. and was distinguished for pushing into close battle,
no and with fixed bayonet an honorable evidence 81
nf his ptrepitv as it is we'll known how seldom bayoe
ck nets are actually crossed in battle even with the
in most veteran corps. 1t at Cowpens that this
mode Of fighting was resorted TO for the first time
mi in he war and the Maryland line so frequent
er " afterwards put to this service, as almost to ans
he te that gallant corps. In this battle Colonel How
,y ard at one llme had in his hand the swords OF seven
,ur officers who had surrendered TO hm personally.
,as During the engagement, having ordered some ove-
ro. ment Of one of the flank companies IT was mistaken
ob by the men for an order to retreat While the line
. was in the act of falling back, Morgan rode up te
ed him excaimng, 9 that the day was lost. Look al
es. that ne, replied Colonel Howard 'Ten who car
,s. retreat in such order, not beaten Morgan het
we pointed out position which he ordered nun to take
Dut and make ST ad but halting bis men, and facing
of them about he poured in sudden fire on the ene'
tie N.Y. and then on his own responsibility. dashed or
The them with the bayonet. 1t on this occasion that
nd he saved the life of the British general u Tiara
er whom he found clngng to his stirrup, and caimn:


in olarter. OHara afterwards addressed to him sew
i'd cral letters. thanking him for his life


ty Colonel Howard continued in his command til
ted the army was dsante, when he retired to is pa
cs trimonia estate near this city. lie soon after mar
civ ried Margaret Chew, the daughter Of Benjamin
the Chcw.of Phatlephia;a lady whose courteous man


ners and elegant hospitality will long be remembered


by the society of this place. of which, as well as o
af tie best company through shout the country her hous
es. was tile ray and easy resort-In November, 1888
MS Colonel Howard was chosen the Governor OF Mary
led land which post he filled for three years. and havin
Ion in the sut,mn of 1906 been elected to the Scnat
ac Of the United States to fill the vacancy occaslone
vas by the resignation Of Mr. Potts, he was- the

full articles.headline: BY AUTHORITY
full articles.article:
CHARLES POLK, Governor of the said State.
10 all persons to whom these presents shall come.
WHEREAS, on the first Tuesday Of October,
being the second day of that month, in the year ofl
our Lord One Thousand Eight Hundred and Twen-
ty-seven, Elections tor choice Of Representative
oi and Tor the SAID State, in the twentieth Congress
OF the United States, IN lieu OF the Honorable Louis
Nj lane, and to supply the vacancy in the Represen
tatlon OF this State, occasoned by his election to,
and acceptance of, the office of Senator for this
State in the Senate OF the United States for the term
OF six years from the fourth day of March last past
were held according to the laws of said State, in the
several Counties thereof, in obedience to wrs of
election for that purpose issued And whereas,
returns for the said elections, in due manner made
out, signed and executed, have been delivered to
me, according to the laws of the said Stae by the
respective Sheriis Of the said Counties, and having
examined SAID returns, and enumerated and
tanned the number of votes, for each and every
didate person voted for as such Representative,
have. found Rensey Johns, Junior, Esquire, to be
the person highest in vote, and therefore duly cleo
ted the Representative of, and for the said State in
lieu of the Honorable Louis M.Lane and 10 supply
the vacancy i'll the Representation of this State for
the Twentieth Congress, in the House of Repre-
sentatives of the United States.


!, the said Charles Polk, Governor aforesaid, do
therefore, according to the form of an act of the
General Assembly Of the said State, in such case
made and provided, declare the said Kensey Johns,
Junior, the person highest in vote at the election
aforesaid, and therefore duly elected the Represen-
latye of and for the said State of Delaware to sup
ply the vacancy aforesaid in the Twentieth Congress
Of the United States.


Given under my hand and the Grca


Seal. Seal of the State, at Dover, this eleventh


S,....s day Of October, in the year Of our Lore
One Thousand Eight Hundred and Twenty
and of the independence Of the said State the Fifty
second,


CHARLES POLK,


BY the Govcrnor.


JOHN NJ. CLAYTON, Secretary of State.
Oct. 15. 5l-4t

THIS Institution will be opened on Monday


the 25th of October Inst, under the care


ofthe Rev. JOSEPH WlLsoS


Tn this Seminary students will be thoroughly in
sructed in the different branches of good English
and Classical Education, viz: Reading. Writing,
Arithmetic, English Grammar, Geography, Comp"-
sit,on. Elocution, Mathematics, and the Greek and
Latin Languages The terms OF tuition will be TOR
the English branches, exclusive of Mathematics,
So per session, or $40, including the Mathematics
for the Languages, including the fnsi'sn' sio per
session. Tuition money to be paid In advance.


There will be two sessions in the year, with
short vacation between each.


Good boarding can be obtalred in respectable,
families in the village, at the rate of Forty Dollars
nor session and few boardcrs can be accommo-
dated in the family of the Principal.


JOHN EDDOWES. Sec'y.

There is, however, one circumstance connected with

The late Dr. Charles Alexander Warfied, of

talon, upon hearing of the arrival of the brig

and which vessel belonged to Mr.. Anthony Stewart,


"a Scotch merchant) put himself at the head OF the
..Whig Club,' Of which he was distinguished
member. and marched to Annapolis with determl-
nation to burn vessel and cargo. When this party
arrived opposite the State House. the late Judge
Chase met them, and harrangued them, (he had been
employed as lawyer by Mr.. Stewart.) DIR. War
field, finding that he was likely to make some i'm


preston upon the minds of his company, interrupt

otto speeches made to the . Whig Clubs" lnAamed


the whole country, and now wished to get ON by his


own light; and pronounced 1T SUBMISSION or cow


ardce in any member of the club TO stop short OF


their object and called upon the men to follow

cargo but it is stated, upon the best authority, that


the doctor carried in his hand the chunk Of fire IN


company with Stewart, whom he made to kindle 1t.


When the party first entered the city and was pas


sing on. they met Stewart, who was bold IN oppps-


tlon and threatened them with the vengeance OF his


king and government, but his threats seemed ony to
Iatp n ual-


lows directly in front of his house, by way OF lntnl-


iation then gave him his choice, either to swing by


the halter, or 20 with them on board Hd put lire to
his own vessel he chose the latter, and in lew

h apparel, were in flames shortly after this, Mr
. Stewart left the country. This act decided the

BIOGRAPHY.

From the Baltimore A,nericdn.
full articles.article:
AZ
4th Of June, 752 in Baltimore county, in this state.
Ills grandfather, Joshua Howard. an Engshnan by
birth. having while yet very young, let his fathers
house in the vicinity of Manchester. to join the army
of the duke Of York, subsequently James II. during
Moumouth's insurrection, was afterwards AFRAID to
encounter his parents dspeasure, and came 10


seek his fortune in America. This was IN the year


lG85-s6. He obtained grantof the land in BaitlA


more county. on which Col. Howard was born,


and which is still in the family, and married Miss


Joanna CARROLL whose father had lately emigrat-


e. from Ireland. Cornelius, one OF his SONS ny this


lady, and father of the subject of this sketch mar


red Miss Ruth Eager. the grand daugh.er of George


Eaoer. whose estate adioined and now makes con-


siderable part of this city. The Eagers came from


England probaby soo after The charter toLord Bali
timore but the records afford little information


prior to 668. when the estate near Baltimore was
purchased. - s


cuIar profession, was destined to that OF arms


by the circumstances of his country. One OF the
first measures Of defence adopted by the colonies
against the mother country was the assemblage OF
4 bodies of the militia, termed flying camps. One OF


these was formed in Maryland in l776, and Mr..


Howard was appointed to Gapta,ncy IN the res'-


ed By Matthew 'Tlghman, the President Of the Cone


yentien of Maryapd is dated the 25tho June, 1776s


a few davs ater he had completed his twenty fourth
year. This corps was dismissed, however, IN the


December of the same year, Congress having rec


qured of each of the states to furnish certain pors


ton Of regular troops, as more effective system
of defence. On the organization OF the seven reSl-
, ments which were to be furnishedby Maryland Cap.
tain Howard, who had been retained by the wish OF
! the Commissioners empowered to appoint officers,
rather than his own, was promoted TO MAJORITY IN


one or tbem the Fourth, under his former comiaile


der, Col. Hall.-His commission IS dated the loth


of Aprl, lT77. On the first June. 1779 he was ape


nointpl Lieutenant Colonel OF the Fifth and IN the


following spring he was transferred to the Sixth, and
: finally after the battle of Hnbkic&s Hill, he succte+


ded to the command of the Second in consequence
! of the death of Lieutenant Colonel Ford, who ne4
= yer recovered of wound received IN t'at battle.
- - OF the services of Colonel Howard during these
" ', wears. and throughout the we have not iimss
y ~ nor is it necessary to speak. In the chvalrous and
: hazardous operations OF Greene in the South, he was
one Of his most efficient and conspicuous coaf5uors.
That gallant General, exact discrimination Of
"a merit pronounced hias coed an officer as the world
= afforded 10 have the best dispositions and corress


pendent ability, to promote the service and to hava
- conf rred great obligations HIMSELF AMI greater
b. on the public. lie deserves said Greene stas
~, tue of gold no less than Roman and Grecian hes


u roas - At the battle of Cowpcns, says Lee, he
,d seized the teal moment, and turned the fortune
"a of he day. He was alike conspicuous, though not
!, alike successful at Guord and the Eutatvs and


- at MI times aud on all occasions eminently useful
vi Besides the battles Just mentioned, he was IN the
!. engagements of White Plains, of Germantown, Of
be Monmouth Camden tlobkick's Hill and others,
ok which may be known to our readers. Having been
IL trained to the service, he employed in that lines
H. and was distinguished for pushing into close battle,
no and with fixed bayonet an honorable evidence 81
nf his ptrepitv as it is we'll known how seldom bayoe
ck nets are actually crossed in battle even with the
in most veteran corps. 1t at Cowpens that this
mode Of fighting was resorted TO for the first time
mi in he war and the Maryland line so frequent
er " afterwards put to this service, as almost to ans
he te that gallant corps. In this battle Colonel How
,y ard at one llme had in his hand the swords OF seven
,ur officers who had surrendered TO hm personally.
,as During the engagement, having ordered some ove-
ro. ment Of one of the flank companies IT was mistaken
ob by the men for an order to retreat While the line
. was in the act of falling back, Morgan rode up te
ed him excaimng, 9 that the day was lost. Look al
es. that ne, replied Colonel Howard 'Ten who car
,s. retreat in such order, not beaten Morgan het
we pointed out position which he ordered nun to take
Dut and make ST ad but halting bis men, and facing
of them about he poured in sudden fire on the ene'
tie N.Y. and then on his own responsibility. dashed or
The them with the bayonet. 1t on this occasion that
nd he saved the life of the British general u Tiara
er whom he found clngng to his stirrup, and caimn:


in olarter. OHara afterwards addressed to him sew
i'd cral letters. thanking him for his life


ty Colonel Howard continued in his command til
ted the army was dsante, when he retired to is pa
cs trimonia estate near this city. lie soon after mar
civ ried Margaret Chew, the daughter Of Benjamin
the Chcw.of Phatlephia;a lady whose courteous man


ners and elegant hospitality will long be remembered


by the society of this place. of which, as well as o
af tie best company through shout the country her hous
es. was tile ray and easy resort-In November, 1888
MS Colonel Howard was chosen the Governor OF Mary
led land which post he filled for three years. and havin
Ion in the sut,mn of 1906 been elected to the Scnat
ac Of the United States to fill the vacancy occaslone
vas by the resignation Of Mr. Potts, he was- the
